elements.title: William H. Davis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that William H. Davis (pictured) was the first teacher of Booker T. Washington and the first African American to be nominated as a candidate for West Virginia governor in 1888?

elements.title: Earlstoun Castle (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ...that defence was not a significant factor in the design or placement of Earlstoun Castle, which was unusual for a 16th-century tower house?

elements.title: Baya Gamani (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Baya Gamani was freed from prison by his captor, King Mohnyin Thado, to defend the capital region of Ava?

elements.title: Two for the Knight (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Manila Standard described the concert Two for the Knight as the "biggest team-up of a foreign and local artist" in the Philippines?

elements.title: Khalil Farah (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that hostile references towards Anglo-Egyptian rule in Sudan by Khalil Farah were hidden in colloquial Sudanese Arabic?

elements.title: a radio station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that when the University of South Dakota started a radio station, the transmitter was built by student and future Nobel Prize winner Ernest Lawrence?

elements.title: Hazelwood massacre (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the 1971 Hazelwood massacre was the largest mass murder in the history of "Murder City"?

elements.title: taxation may have played a part (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that taxation may have played a part in the fall of the Roman Empire?
